017package com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure.cielab;
018
019import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure.FloatColors;
020import com.github.tommyettinger.digital.BitConversion;
021import com.github.tommyettinger.digital.MathTools;
022import com.github.tommyettinger.digital.TrigTools;
023
024import java.util.Random;
025
026/**
027 * Contains code for manipulating colors as {@code int} and packed {@code float} values in the CIE L*A*B* color space.
028 * This is the old standard (and for some things, gold standard) of color spaces, introduced in 1976 and never fully
029 * superseded by a newer color space. A reason there are still newer color spaces being introduced is in part that
030 * existing color spaces, such as CIELAB, don't have sufficient performance for a given task, and this is an especially
031 * fair criticism of CIELAB -- it's slow. But, if you calculate new colors infrequently and do the heaviest conversions
032 * in a shader, this might not be noticeably different from Oklab or IPT_HQ. This package emphasizes quality over speed,
033 * so some calculations that are approximated in Oklab and IPT_HQ are performed rigorously here.
034 * <br>
035 * The CIE L*A*B* color space has 3 channels, L, A, and B, each gamma-corrected (which is why an asterisk is added).
036 * L is lightness, A is a chroma axis that is (roughly) cyan-vs.-red, and B is a chroma axis that is (roughly)
037 * blue-vs.-yellow. This is the same in concept as Oklab, but Oklab is skewed somewhat so high B there is more orange
038 * than yellow; it's somewhat hard to accurately produce yellow in Oklab. This also has an alpha channel in each color,
039 * which acts like it does in every other color space package here (multiplicative alpha, higher is more opaque).
040 */
041public class ColorTools {
042    /**
043     * Gets a packed float representation of a color given as 4 float components, here, L (luminance or lightness), A
044     * (a chromatic component ranging from cyan to red), B (a chromatic component ranging from blue to yellow), and
045     * alpha (or opacity). L should be between 0 and 1, inclusive, with 0 used for very dark colors (almost only black),
046     * and 1 used for very light colors (almost only white). A and B range from 0.0 to 1.0, with grayscale results when
047     * both are about 0.5. There's some aesthetic value in changing just one chroma value. When A is high and B is low,
048     * the color is more purple/magenta, when both are low it is more bluish, when B is high and A is low, the color
049     * tends to be greenish, and when both are high it tends to be orange. When A and B are both near 0.5f, the color is
050     * closer to gray. Alpha is the multiplicative opacity of the color, and acts like RGBA's alpha.
051     *
052     * @param l     0f to 1f, lightness or L component of CIELAB, with 0.5f meaning "no change" and 1f brightening
053     * @param a     0f to 1f, A component of CIELAB, with 1f more orange, red, or magenta
054     * @param b     0f to 1f, B component of CIELAB, with 1f more green, yellow, or red
055     * @param alpha 0f to 1f, 0f makes the color transparent and 1f makes it opaque
056     * @return a float encoding a color with the given properties
057     */
058    public static float cielab(float l, float a, float b, float alpha) {
059        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (alpha * 255.999f) << 24 & 0xFE000000) | ((int) (b * 255.999f) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
060                | ((int) (a * 255.999f) << 8 & 0xFF00) | ((int) (l * 255.999f) & 0xFF));
061    }
062    /**
063     * Gets a packed float representation of a color given as 4 float components, L, A, B, and alpha, with each
064     * component clamped to the 0f to 1f range before being entered into the packed float color. This is only different
065     * from {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)} in that it clamps each component. It still permits out-of-gamut
066     * colors to be stored, but as long as the rendering code (such as a shader or ColorfulBatch) does its own
067     * validation or correction of colors, then having out-of-gamut colors shouldn't be a problem.
068     *
069     * @see #cielab(float, float, float, float) This uses the same definitions for L, A, B, and alpha as cielab().
070     * @param l     0f to 1f, lightness or L component of CIELAB, with 0.5f meaning "no change" and 1f brightening
071     * @param a     0f to 1f, A component of CIELAB, with 1f more orange, red, or magenta
072     * @param b     0f to 1f, B component of CIELAB, with 1f more green, yellow, or red
073     * @param alpha 0f to 1f, 0f makes the color transparent and 1f makes it opaque
074     * @return a float encoding a color with the given properties
075     */
076    public static float clamp(float l, float a, float b, float alpha) {
077        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((Math.min(Math.max((int) (alpha * 127.999f), 0), 127) << 25)
078                | (Math.min(Math.max((int) (b * 255.999f), 0), 255) << 16)
079                | (Math.min(Math.max((int) (a * 255.999f), 0), 255) << 8)
080                | (Math.min(Math.max((int) (l * 255.999f), 0), 255))
081        );
082    }
083
084
085    /**
086     * An approximation of the cube-root function for float inputs and outputs.
087     * This can be about twice as fast as {@link Math#cbrt(double)}. This
088     * version does not tolerate negative inputs, because in the narrow use
089     * case it has in this class, it never is given negative inputs.
090     * <br>
091     * Has very low relative error (less than 1E-9) when inputs are uniformly
092     * distributed between 0 and 512, and absolute mean error of less than
093     * 1E-6 in the same scenario. Uses a bit-twiddling method similar to one
094     * presented in Hacker's Delight and also used in early 3D graphics (see
095     * https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fast_inverse_square_root for more, but
096     * this code approximates cbrt(x) and not 1/sqrt(x)). This specific code
097     * was originally by Marc B. Reynolds, posted in his "Stand-alone-junk"
098     * repo: https://github.com/Marc-B-Reynolds/Stand-alone-junk/blob/master/src/Posts/ballcube.c#L182-L197 .
099     * It's worth noting that while hardware instructions for finding the
100     * square root of a float have gotten extremely fast, the same is not
101     * true for the cube root (which has to allow negative inputs), so while
102     * the bit-twiddling inverse square root is no longer a beneficial
103     * optimization on current hardware, this does seem to help.
104     * <br>
105     * This is used when converting from RGB to CIELAB, as an intermediate step.
106     * @param x any non-negative finite float to find the cube root of
107     * @return the cube root of x, approximated
108     */
109    private static float cbrtPositive(float x) {
110        int ix = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(x);
111        final float x0 = x;
112        ix = (ix>>>2) + (ix>>>4);
113        ix += (ix>>>4);
114        ix += (ix>>>8) + 0x2A5137A0;
115        x  = BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(ix);
116        x  = 0.33333334f*(2f * x + x0/(x*x));
117        x  = 0.33333334f*(1.9999999f * x + x0/(x*x));
118        return x;
119    }
120
121    /**
122     * Used when given non-linear sRGB inputs to make them linear, using an exact gamma of 2.4 and accounting for the
123     * darkest colors with a different formula.
124     * @param component any non-linear channel of a color, to be made linear
125     * @return a linear version of component
126     */
127    private static float forwardGamma(final float component) {
128        return component < 0.04045f ? component * (1f/12.92f) : (float)Math.pow((component + 0.055f) * (1f/1.055f), 2.4f);
129    }
130
131    /**
132     * Used to return from a linear, gamma-corrected input to an sRGB, non-linear output, using an exact gamma of 2.4
133     * and accounting for the darkest colors with a different formula.
134     * @param component a linear channel of a color, to be made non-linear
135     * @return a non-linear version of component
136     */
137    private static float reverseGamma(final float component) {
138        return component < 0.0031308f ? component * 12.92f : (float)Math.pow(component, 1f/2.4f) * 1.055f - 0.055f;
139    }
140
141    private static float forwardXYZ(final float t) {
142        return (t < 0.00885645f) ? 7.787037f * t + 0.139731f : cbrtPositive(t);
143    }
144
145    private static float reverseXYZ(final float t) {
146        return (t < 0.20689655f) ? 0.1284185f * (t - 0.139731f) : t * t * t;
147    }
148
149    /**
150     * Converts a packed float color in the format produced by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)} to an RGBA8888 int.
151     * This format of int can be used with Pixmap and in some other places in libGDX.
152     * @param packed a packed float color, as produced by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
153     * @return an RGBA8888 int color
154     */
155    public static int toRGBA8888(final float packed)
156    {
157        final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
158        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*((decoded & 0xff) / 255f + 0.16f);
159        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.2f / 127.5f);
160        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
161        final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A);
162        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
163        final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B);
164        final int r = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
165        final int g = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
166        final int b = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
167        return r << 24 | g << 16 | b << 8 | (decoded & 0xfe000000) >>> 24 | decoded >>> 31;
168    }
169
170    /**
171     * Converts a packed float color in the format produced by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
172     * to a packed float in ABGR8888 format.
173     * This format of float can be used with the standard SpriteBatch and in some other places in libGDX.
174     * @param packed a packed float color, as produced by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
175     * @return a packed float color as ABGR8888
176     */
177    public static float toRGBA(final float packed)
178    {
179        final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
180        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*((decoded & 0xff) / 255f + 0.16f);
181        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.2f / 127.5f);
182        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
183        final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A);
184        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
185        final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B);
186        final int r = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
187        final int g = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
188        final int b = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
189        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(r | g << 8 | b << 16 | (decoded & 0xfe000000));
190    }
191
192    /**
193     * Takes a color encoded as an RGBA8888 int and converts to a packed float in the CIELAB format this uses.
194     * @param rgba an int with the channels (in order) red, green, blue, alpha; should have 8 bits per channel
195     * @return a packed float as CIELAB, which this class can use
196     */
197    public static float fromRGBA8888(final int rgba) {
198        final float r = forwardGamma((rgba >>> 24) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
199        final float g = forwardGamma((rgba >>> 16 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
200        final float b = forwardGamma((rgba >>> 8 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
201
202        final float x = forwardXYZ(0.4124564f * r  + 0.3575761f * g + 0.1804375f * b);
203        final float y = forwardXYZ(0.2126729f * r  + 0.7151522f * g + 0.0721750f * b);
204        final float z = forwardXYZ(0.0193339f * r  + 0.1191920f * g + 0.9503041f * b);
205
206        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(
207                          Math.min(Math.max((int)((1.16f*y - 0.16f) * 255.999f    ), 0), 255)
208                        | Math.min(Math.max((int)((x - y) * (127.999f * 5f) + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 8
209                        | Math.min(Math.max((int)((y - z) * (127.999f * 2f) + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 16
210                        | (rgba & 0xFE) << 24);
211    }
212
213    /**
214     * Takes a color encoded as an ABGR packed float and converts to a packed float in the CIELAB format this uses.
215     * @param packed a packed float in ABGR8888 format, with A in the MSB and R in the LSB
216     * @return a packed float as CIELAB, which this class can use
217     */
218    public static float fromRGBA(final float packed) {
219        final int abgr = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
220        final float r = forwardGamma((abgr & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
221        final float g = forwardGamma((abgr >>> 8 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
222        final float b = forwardGamma((abgr >>> 16 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
223
224        final float x = forwardXYZ(0.4124564f * r + 0.3575761f * g + 0.1804375f * b);
225        final float y = forwardXYZ(0.2126729f * r + 0.7151522f * g + 0.0721750f * b);
226        final float z = forwardXYZ(0.0193339f * r + 0.1191920f * g + 0.9503041f * b);
227
228        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(
229                          Math.min(Math.max((int)((1.16f*y - 0.16f) * 255.999f    ), 0), 255)
230                        | Math.min(Math.max((int)(((x - y)) * (127.999f * 5f) + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 8
231                        | Math.min(Math.max((int)(((y - z)) * (127.999f * 2f) + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 16
232                        | (abgr & 0xFE000000));
233    }
234
235    /**
236     * Takes RGBA components from 0.0 to 1.0 each and converts to a packed float in the CIELAB format this uses.
237     * @param r red, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
238     * @param g green, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
239     * @param b blue, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
240     * @param a alpha, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
241     * @return a packed float as CIELAB, which this class can use
242     */
243    public static float fromRGBA(float r, float g, float b, final float a) {
244        r = forwardGamma(r);
245        g = forwardGamma(g);
246        b = forwardGamma(b);
247        final float x = forwardXYZ(0.4124564f * r + 0.3575761f * g + 0.1804375f * b);
248        final float y = forwardXYZ(0.2126729f * r + 0.7151522f * g + 0.0721750f * b);
249        final float z = forwardXYZ(0.0193339f * r + 0.1191920f * g + 0.9503041f * b);
250        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(
251                          Math.min(Math.max((int)((1.16f*y - 0.16f) * 255.999f    ), 0), 255)
252                        | Math.min(Math.max((int)(((x - y)) * (127.999f * 5f) + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 8
253                        | Math.min(Math.max((int)(((y - z)) * (127.999f * 2f) + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 16
254                        | ((int)(a * 255f) << 24 & 0xFE000000));
255    }
256
257        /**
258         * Gets the red channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
259         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
260         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the red channel value of the given encoded color
261         */
262        public static int redInt(final float encoded)
263        {
264        final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
265        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*((decoded & 0xff) / 255f + 0.16f);
266        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) *  (0.2f / 127.5f);
267        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
268        final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A);
269        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
270        final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B);
271        return (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
272        }
273
274        /**
275         * Gets the green channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
276         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
277         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the green channel value of the given encoded color
278         */
279        public static int greenInt(final float encoded)
280        {
281        final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
282        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*((decoded & 0xff) / 255f + 0.16f);
283        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) *  (0.2f / 127.5f);
284        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
285        final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A);
286        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
287        final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B);
288        return (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
289        }
290
291        /**
292         * Gets the blue channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
293         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
294         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the blue channel value of the given encoded color
295         */
296        public static int blueInt(final float encoded)
297        {
298        final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
299        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*((decoded & 0xff) / 255f + 0.16f);
300        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) *  (0.2f / 127.5f);
301        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
302        final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A);
303        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
304        final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B);
305        return (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
306        }
307
308        /**
309         * Gets the alpha channel value of the given encoded color, as an even int ranging from 0 to 254, inclusive. Because
310         * of how alpha is stored in libGDX, no odd-number values are possible for alpha.
311         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
312         * @return an even int from 0 to 254, inclusive, representing the alpha channel value of the given encoded color
313         */
314        public static int alphaInt(final float encoded)
315        {
316                return (BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xfe000000) >>> 24;
317        }
318    /**
319     * Gets the red channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
320     * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
321     * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the red channel value of the given encoded color
322     */
323    public static float red(final float encoded)
324    {
325        final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
326        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*((decoded & 0xff) / 255f + 0.16f);
327        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) *  (0.2f / 127.5f);
328        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
329        final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A);
330        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
331        final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B);
332        return reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z, 0f), 1f));
333    }
334
335    /**
336     * Gets the green channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
337     * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
338     * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the green channel value of the given encoded color
339     */
340    public static float green(final float encoded)
341    {
342        final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
343        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*((decoded & 0xff) / 255f + 0.16f);
344        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) *  (0.2f / 127.5f);
345        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
346        final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A);
347        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
348        final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B);
349        return reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z, 0f), 1f));
350    }
351
352    /**
353     * Gets the blue channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
354     * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
355     * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the blue channel value of the given encoded color
356     */
357    public static float blue(final float encoded)
358    {
359        final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
360        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*((decoded & 0xff) / 255f + 0.16f);
361        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) *  (0.2f / 127.5f);
362        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
363        final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A);
364        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
365        final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B);
366        return reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z, 0f), 1f));
367    }
368
369    /**
370     * Gets the alpha channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
371     * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
372     * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the alpha channel value of the given encoded color
373     */
374    public static float alpha(final float encoded)
375    {
376        return ((BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xfe000000) >>> 24) * 0x1.020408p-8f;
377    }
378
379
380    /**
381     * Gets the "chroma" or "colorfulness" of a given CIELAB color. Chroma is similar to saturation in that grayscale
382     * values have 0 saturation and 0 chroma, while brighter colors have high saturation and chroma. The difference is
383     * that colors that are perceptually more-colorful have higher chroma than colors that are perceptually
384     * less-colorful, regardless of hue, whereas saturation changes its meaning depending on the hue and lightness. That
385     * is, the most saturated color for a given hue and lightness always has a saturation of 1, but if that color
386     * isn't perceptually very colorful (as is the case for very dark and very light colors), it will have a chroma that
387     * is much lower than the maximum. The result of this method can't be negative, grayscale values have very close to
388     * 0 chroma, and the most colorful value (a shade of purple) should have 1.26365817 chroma.
389     * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
390     * @return a float between 0.0f and 1.26365817 that represents how colorful the given value is
391     */
392    public static float chroma(final float encoded) {
393        final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
394        final float a = ((decoded >>> 7 & 0x1FE) - 255) / 255f;
395        final float b = ((decoded >>> 15 & 0x1FE) - 255) / 255f;
396        return (float) Math.sqrt(a * a + b * b);
397    }
398    /**
399     * Given a hue and lightness, this gets the (very approximate) maximum chroma possible for that hue-lightness
400     * combination, using CIELAB's versions of lightness and hue (not HSL). This is useful to know the bounds of
401     * {@link #chroma(float)}. This should be no greater than 1.26365817f . Note that this version of chromaLimit() is
402     * much slower than Oklab's version, because this has to go to much greater lengths to become accurate.
403     * @param hue the hue, typically between 0.0f and 1.0f, to look up
404     * @param lightness the lightness, clamped between 0.0f and 1.0f, to look up
405     * @return the maximum possible chroma for the given hue and lightness, between 0.0f and 1.26365817f
406     */
407    public static float chromaLimit(final float hue, final float lightness) {
408        final float h = hue - MathTools.floor(hue);
409        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*(lightness + 0.16f);
410        final float A = TrigTools.cosTurns(h) * (1.26365817f);
411        final float B = TrigTools.sinTurns(h) * (1.26365817f);
412        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
413        float A2 = A, B2 = B;
414        for (int attempt = 127; attempt >= 0; attempt--) {
415            final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A2);
416            final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B2);
417            final float r = reverseGamma(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z);
418            final float g = reverseGamma(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z);
419            final float b = reverseGamma(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z);
420            if(r >= 0f && r <= 1f && g >= 0f && g <= 1f && b >= 0f && b <= 1f)
421                break;
422            final float progress = attempt * 0x1p-7f;
423            A2 = (A * progress);
424            B2 = (B * progress);
425        }
426        return (float) Math.sqrt(A2 * A2 + B2 * B2);
427    }
428    /**
429     * Gets the color with the same L as the CIELAB color stored in the given packed float, but the furthest A
430     * B from gray possible for that lightness while keeping the same hue as the given color. This is very
431     * similar to calling {@link #enrich(float, float)} with a very large {@code change} value.
432     * @param packed a packed float color in CIELAB format; does not need to be in-gamut
433     * @return the color that is as far from grayscale as this can get while keeping the L and hue of packed
434     * @see #limitToGamut(float) You can use limitToGamut() if you only want max saturation for out-of-gamut colors.
435     */
436    public static float maximizeSaturation(final float packed) {
437        final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
438        final float lightness = (decoded & 255) / 255f;
439        final float h = TrigTools.atan2Turns(((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f), ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f));
440        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*(lightness + 0.16f);
441        final float A = TrigTools.cosTurns(h) * 1.26365817f * 0.2f;
442        final float B = TrigTools.sinTurns(h) * 1.26365817f * 0.5f;
443        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
444        float A2 = A, B2 = B;
445        for (int attempt = 127; attempt >= 0; attempt--) {
446            final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A2);
447            final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B2);
448            final float r = reverseGamma(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z);
449            final float g = reverseGamma(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z);
450            final float b = reverseGamma(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z);
451            if(r >= 0f && r <= 1f && g >= 0f && g <= 1f && b >= 0f && b <= 1f)
452                break;
453            final float progress = attempt * 0x1p-7f;
454            A2 = (A * progress);
455            B2 = (B * progress);
456        }
457        return cielab(lightness, A2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, B2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, (decoded >>> 25) / 127f);
458    }
459    /**
460     * Gets the color with the same L as the CIELAB color stored in the given packed float, but the furthest A
461     * B from gray possible for that lightness while keeping the same hue as the given color. This is very
462     * similar to calling {@link #enrich(float, float)} with a very large {@code change} value.
463     * @param L lightness component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
464     * @param A green-to-red chromatic component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
465     * @param B blue-to-yellow chromatic component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
466     * @param alpha alpha component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
467     * @return the color that is as far from grayscale as this can get while keeping the L and hue of packed
468     * @see #limitToGamut(float, float, float, float) You can use limitToGamut() if you only want max saturation
469     * for out-of-gamut colors.
470     */
471    public static float maximizeSaturation(float L, float A, float B, float alpha) {
472        L = Math.min(Math.max(L, 0f), 1f);
473        A = Math.min(Math.max(A, 0f), 1f);
474        B = Math.min(Math.max(B, 0f), 1f);
475        alpha = Math.min(Math.max(alpha, 0f), 1f);
476        final float h = TrigTools.atan2Turns(B - 0.5f, A - 0.5f);
477        final float L0 = (1f/1.16f)*(L + 0.16f);
478        final float A0 = TrigTools.cosTurns(h) * 1.26365817f;
479        final float B0 = TrigTools.sinTurns(h) * 1.26365817f;
480        final float y = reverseXYZ(L0);
481        float A2 = A0, B2 = B0;
482        for (int attempt = 127; attempt >= 0; attempt--) {
483            final float x = reverseXYZ(L0 + A2);
484            final float z = reverseXYZ(L0 - B2);
485            final float r = reverseGamma(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z);
486            final float g = reverseGamma(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z);
487            final float b = reverseGamma(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z);
488            if(r >= 0f && r <= 1f && g >= 0f && g <= 1f && b >= 0f && b <= 1f)
489                break;
490            final float progress = attempt * 0x1p-7f;
491            A2 = (A0 * progress);
492            B2 = (B0 * progress);
493        }
494        return cielab(L, A2, B2, alpha);
495    }
496
497    /**
498     * Gets the hue of the given CIELAB float color, but as CIELAB understands hue rather than how HSL does.
499     * This is different from {@link #hue(float)}, which uses HSL. This gives a float between 0 (inclusive)
500     * and 1 (exclusive).
501     *
502     * @param packed a packed CIELAB float color
503     * @return a float between 0 (inclusive) and 1 (exclusive) that represents hue in the CIELAB color space
504     */
505    public static float cielabHue(final float packed) {
506        final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
507        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) *  (0.2f / 127.5f);
508        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
509        return TrigTools.atan2Turns(B, A);
510    }
511
512    /**
513     * Gets the saturation of the given CIELAB float color, but as CIELAB understands saturation rather than how HSL
514     * does. Saturation here is a fraction of the chroma limit (see {@link #chromaLimit(float, float)}) for a given hue
515     * and lightness, and is between 0 and 1. This gives a float between 0 (inclusive) and 1 (inclusive).
516     *
517     * @param packed a packed CIELAB float color
518     * @return a float between 0 (inclusive) and 1 (inclusive) that represents saturation in the CIELAB color space
519     */
520    public static float cielabSaturation(final float packed) {
521        final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
522        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*(((decoded & 0xff) / 255f) + 0.16f);
523        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) *  (0.2f / 127.5f);
524        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
525        final float h = TrigTools.atan2Turns(B, A);
526        final float L0 = (1f/1.16f)*(L + 0.16f);
527        final float A0 = TrigTools.cosTurns(h) * 1.26365817f;
528        final float B0 = TrigTools.sinTurns(h) * 1.26365817f;
529        final float y = reverseXYZ(L0);
530        float A2 = A0, B2 = B0;
531        for (int attempt = 127; attempt >= 0; attempt--) {
532            final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A2);
533            final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B2);
534            final float r = reverseGamma(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z);
535            final float g = reverseGamma(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z);
536            final float b = reverseGamma(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z);
537            if(r >= 0f && r <= 1f && g >= 0f && g <= 1f && b >= 0f && b <= 1f)
538                break;
539            final float progress = attempt * 0x1p-7f;
540            A2 = (A0 * progress);
541            B2 = (B0 * progress);
542        }
543        final float dist = (float) Math.sqrt(A2 * A2 + B2 * B2);
544        return (float) Math.sqrt(A * A + B * B) / dist;
545    }
546    /**
547     * Gets the lightness of the given CIELAB float color, but as CIELAB understands lightness rather than how HSL does.
548     * This is different from {@link #lightness(float)}, which uses HSL. This gives a float between 0 (inclusive)
549     * and 1 (inclusive).
550     * <br>
551     * This is the same as {@link #channelL(float)}.
552     *
553     * @param packed a packed CIELAB float color
554     * @return a float between 0 (inclusive) and 1 (inclusive) that represents lightness in the CIELAB color space
555     */
556    public static float cielabLightness(final float packed){
557        return (BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed) & 0xff) / 255f;
558    }
559
560    /**
561     * A different way to specify a CIELAB color, using hue, saturation, lightness, and alpha like a normal HSL(A) color
562     * but calculating them directly in the CIELAB color space. This is more efficient than
563     * {@link #floatGetHSL(float, float, float, float)}. You may prefer using
564     * {@link #cielabByHCL(float, float, float, float)}, which takes an absolute chroma as opposed to the saturation
565     * here (which is a fraction of the maximum chroma).
566     * <br>
567     * Note that this takes a different value for its {@code hue} that the method {@link #hue(float)} produces, just
568     * like its {@code saturation} and the method {@link #saturation(float)}, and {@code lightness} and the method
569     * {@link #lightness(float)}. The hue is just distributed differently, and the lightness should be equivalent to
570     * {@link #channelL(float)}, but the saturation here refers to what fraction the chroma should be of the maximum
571     * chroma for the given hue and lightness. You can use {@link #cielabHue(float)}, {@link #cielabSaturation(float)},
572     * and {@link #cielabLightness(float)} to get the hue, saturation, and lightness values from an existing color that
573     * this will understand ({@link #alpha(float)} too). This method is likely to be significantly slower than
574     * {@link #cielabByHCL(float, float, float, float)} because this needs to calculate the gamut.
575     * @param hue between 0 and 1, usually, but this will automatically wrap if too high or too low
576     * @param saturation will be clamped between 0 and 1
577     * @param lightness will be clamped between 0 and 1
578     * @param alpha will be clamped between 0 and 1
579     * @return a packed CIELAB float color that tries to match the requested hue, saturation, and lightness
580     */
581    public static float cielabByHSL(float hue, float saturation, float lightness, float alpha) {
582        lightness = Math.min(Math.max(lightness, 0f), 1f);
583        saturation = Math.min(Math.max(saturation, 0f), 1f);
584        hue -= MathTools.floor(hue);
585        alpha = Math.min(Math.max(alpha, 0f), 1f);
586        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*(lightness + 0.16f);
587        final float L0 = (1f/1.16f)*(L + 0.16f);
588        final float cos = TrigTools.cosTurns(hue);
589        final float sin = TrigTools.sinTurns(hue);
590        final float A0 = cos * 1.26365817f * 0.2f;
591        final float B0 = sin * 1.26365817f * 0.5f;
592        final float y = reverseXYZ(L0);
593        float A2 = A0, B2 = B0;
594        for (int attempt = 127; attempt >= 0; attempt--) {
595            final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A2);
596            final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B2);
597            final float r = reverseGamma(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z);
598            final float g = reverseGamma(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z);
599            final float b = reverseGamma(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z);
600            if(r >= 0f && r <= 1f && g >= 0f && g <= 1f && b >= 0f && b <= 1f)
601                break;
602            final float progress = attempt * 0x1p-7f;
603            A2 = (A0 * progress);
604            B2 = (B0 * progress);
605        }
606        final float dist = (float) Math.sqrt(A2 * A2 + B2 * B2) * saturation;
607        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(
608                (int) (alpha * 127.999f) << 25 |
609                        Math.min(Math.max((int) (sin * dist + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 16 |
610                        Math.min(Math.max((int) (cos * dist + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 8 |
611                        (int) (lightness * 255.999f));
612    }
613
614    /**
615     * A different way to specify a CIELAB color, using hue, chroma, lightness, and alpha something like a normal HSL(A)
616     * color but calculating them directly in the CIELAB color space. This has you specify the desired chroma directly,
617     * as obtainable with {@link #chroma(float)}, rather than the saturation, which is a fraction of the maximum chroma
618     * (saturation is what {@link #cielabByHSL(float, float, float, float)} uses). Note that this takes a different
619     * value for its {@code hue} that the method {@link #hue(float)} produces, just like {@code lightness} and the
620     * method {@link #lightness(float)}. The hue is just distributed differently, and the lightness should be equivalent
621     * to {@link #channelL(float)}. If you use this to get two colors with the same chroma and lightness, but different
622     * hue, then the resulting colors should have similar colorfulness unless one or both chroma values exceeded the
623     * gamut limit (you can get this limit with {@link #chromaLimit(float, float)}). If a chroma value given is greater
624     * than the chroma limit, this clamps chroma to that limit. You can use {@link #cielabHue(float)},
625     * {@link #chroma(float)}, and {@link #cielabLightness(float)} to get the hue, chroma, and lightness values from an
626     * existing color that this will understand ({@link #alpha(float)} too). This method should be significantly faster
627     * than {@link #cielabByHSL(float, float, float, float)} because it doesn't need to calculate the gamut.
628     * @param hue between 0 and 1, usually, but this will automatically wrap if too high or too low
629     * @param chroma will be clamped between 0 and the maximum chroma possible for the given hue and lightness
630     * @param lightness will be clamped between 0 and 1
631     * @param alpha will be clamped between 0 and 1
632     * @return a packed CIELAB float color that tries to match the requested hue, chroma, and lightness
633     */
634    public static float cielabByHCL(float hue, float chroma, float lightness, float alpha) {
635        lightness = Math.min(Math.max(lightness, 0f), 1f);
636        chroma = Math.max(chroma, 0f) * 127.5f;
637        hue -= MathTools.floor(hue);
638        alpha = Math.min(Math.max(alpha, 0f), 1f);
639        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(
640                (int) (alpha * 127.999f) << 25 |
641                        Math.min(Math.max((int) (TrigTools.sinTurns(hue) /* * 2f */ * chroma + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 16 |
642                        Math.min(Math.max((int) (TrigTools.cosTurns(hue) /* * 5f */ * chroma + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 8 |
643                        (int) (lightness * 255.999f));
644    }
645
646    /**
647     * Gets a color as a CIELAB packed float given floats representing hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity.
648     * All parameters should normally be between 0 and 1 inclusive, though any hue is tolerated (precision loss may
649     * affect the color if the hue is too large). A hue of 0 is red, progressively higher hue values go to orange,
650     * yellow, green, blue, and purple before wrapping around to red as it approaches 1. A saturation of 0 is grayscale,
651     * a saturation of 1 is brightly colored, and values close to 1 will usually appear more distinct than values close
652     * to 0, especially if the hue is different. A lightness of 0.001f or less is always black (also using a shortcut if
653     * this is the case, respecting opacity), while a lightness of 1f is white. Very bright colors are mostly in a band
654     * of high-saturation where lightness is 0.5f.
655     *
656     * @param hue        0f to 1f, color wheel position
657     * @param saturation 0f to 1f, 0f is grayscale and 1f is brightly colored
658     * @param lightness  0f to 1f, 0f is black and 1f is white
659     * @param opacity    0f to 1f, 0f is fully transparent and 1f is opaque
660     * @return a CIELAB float encoding a color with the given properties
661     */
662    public static float floatGetHSL(float hue, float saturation, float lightness, float opacity) {
663        if (lightness <= 0.001f) {
664            return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((((int) (opacity * 255f) << 24) & 0xFE000000) | 0x7F7F00);
665        } else {
666            return fromRGBA(FloatColors.hsl2rgb(hue, saturation, lightness, opacity));
667        }
668    }
669
670    /**
671     * Gets the saturation of the given encoded color as HSL would calculate it, as a float ranging from 0.0f to 1.0f,
672     * inclusive. This is different from {@link #chroma(float)}; see that method's documentation for details.
673     *
674     * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
675     * @return the saturation of the color from 0.0 (a grayscale color; inclusive) to 1.0 (a bright color, inclusive)
676     */
677    public static float saturation(final float encoded) {
678        final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
679        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*((decoded & 0xff) / 255f + 0.16f);
680        if(Math.abs(L - 0.5) > 0.495f) return 0f;
681        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) *  (0.2f / 127.5f);
682        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
683        final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A);
684        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
685        final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B);
686        final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z, 0f), 1f));
687        final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z, 0f), 1f));
688        final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z, 0f), 1f));
689        float X, Y, W;
690        if(g < b) {
691            X = b;
692            Y = g;
693        }
694        else {
695            X = g;
696            Y = b;
697        }
698        if(r < X) {
699            W = r;
700        }
701        else {
702            W = X;
703            X = r;
704        }
705        return X - Math.min(W, Y);
706    }
707
708    /**
709     * Defined as per HSL; normally you only need {@link #channelL(float)} to get accurate lightness for CIELAB. This
710     * ranges from 0.0f (black) to 1.0f (white).
711     *
712     * @param encoded a packed float CIELAB color
713     * @return the lightness of the given color as HSL would calculate it
714     */
715    public static float lightness(final float encoded) {
716        final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
717        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*((decoded & 0xff) / 255f + 0.16f);
718        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) *  (0.2f / 127.5f);
719        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
720        final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A);
721        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
722        final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B);
723        final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z, 0f), 1f));
724        final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z, 0f), 1f));
725        final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z, 0f), 1f));
726        float X, Y, W;
727        if(g < b) {
728            X = b;
729            Y = g;
730        }
731        else {
732            X = g;
733            Y = b;
734        }
735        if(r < X) {
736            W = r;
737        }
738        else {
739            W = X;
740            X = r;
741        }
742        float d = X - Math.min(W, Y);
743        return X * (1f - 0.5f * d / (X + 1e-10f));
744    }
745
746    /**
747     * Gets the hue of the given encoded color, as a float from 0f (inclusive, red and approaching orange if increased)
748     * to 1f (exclusive, red and approaching purple if decreased).
749     *
750     * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
751     * @return The hue of the color from 0.0 (red, inclusive) towards orange, then yellow, and
752     * eventually to purple before looping back to almost the same red (1.0, exclusive)
753     */
754    public static float hue(final float encoded) {
755        final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
756        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*((decoded & 0xff) / 255f + 0.16f);
757        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) *  (0.2f / 127.5f);
758        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
759        final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A);
760        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
761        final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B);
762        final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z, 0f), 1f));
763        final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z, 0f), 1f));
764        final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z, 0f), 1f));
765        float X, Y, Z, W;
766        if(g < b) {
767            X = b;
768            Y = g;
769            Z = -1f;
770            W = 2f / 3f;
771        }
772        else {
773            X = g;
774            Y = b;
775            Z = 0f;
776            W = -1f / 3f;
777        }
778        if(r < X) {
779            Z = W;
780            W = r;
781        }
782        else {
783            W = X;
784            X = r;
785        }
786        float d = X - Math.min(W, Y);
787        return Math.abs(Z + (W - Y) / (6f * d + 1e-10f));
788    }
789    /**
790     * Gets a variation on the packed float color basis as another packed float that has its hue, saturation, lightness,
791     * and opacity adjusted by the specified amounts. Note that this edits the color in HSL space, not CIELAB! Takes
792     * floats representing the amounts of change to apply to hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity; these can be
793     * between -1f and 1f. Returns a float that can be used as a packed or encoded color. The float is likely to be
794     * different than the result of {@code basis} unless hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity are all 0.
795     * This won't allocate any objects.
796     * <br>
797     * The parameters this takes all specify additive changes for a color component, clamping the final values so they
798     * can't go above 1 or below 0, with an exception for hue, which can rotate around if lower or higher hues would be
799     * used. As an example, if you give this 0.4f for saturation, and the current color has saturation 0.7f, then the
800     * resulting color will have 1f for saturation. If you gave this -0.1f for saturation and the current color again
801     * has saturation 0.7f, then resulting color will have 0.6f for saturation.
802     *
803     * @param basis      a packed float color that will be used as the starting point to make the next color
804     * @param hue        -1f to 1f, the hue change that can be applied to the new float color (not clamped, wraps)
805     * @param saturation -1f to 1f, the saturation change that can be applied to the new float color
806     * @param light      -1f to 1f, the light/brightness change that can be applied to the new float color
807     * @param opacity    -1f to 1f, the opacity/alpha change that can be applied to the new float color
808     * @return a float encoding a variation of basis with the given changes
809     */
810    public static float toEditedFloat(float basis, float hue, float saturation, float light, float opacity) {
811        final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(basis);
812        final float li = Math.min(Math.max(light + (decoded & 0xff) / 255f, 0f), 1f);
813        opacity = Math.min(Math.max(opacity + (decoded >>> 25) * (1f / 127f), 0f), 1f);
814        if (li <= 0.001f)
815            return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((((int) (opacity * 255f) << 24) & 0xFE000000) | 0x808000);
816        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*(li + 0.16f);
817        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) *  (0.2f / 127.5f);
818        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
819        final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A);
820        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
821        final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B);
822        final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z, 0f), 1f));
823        final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z, 0f), 1f));
824        final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z, 0f), 1f));
825        float X, Y, Z, W;
826        if(g < b) {
827            X = b;
828            Y = g;
829            Z = -1f;
830            W = 2f / 3f;
831        }
832        else {
833            X = g;
834            Y = b;
835            Z = 0f;
836            W = -1f / 3f;
837        }
838        if(r < X) {
839            Z = W;
840            W = r;
841        }
842        else {
843            W = X;
844            X = r;
845        }
846        final float d = X - Math.min(W, Y);
847        final float lum = X * (1f - 0.5f * d / (X + 1e-10f));
848        hue += Math.abs(Z + (W - Y) / (6f * d + 1e-10f)) + 1f;
849        saturation += (X - lum) / (Math.min(lum, 1f - lum) + 1e-10f);
850        return fromRGBA(FloatColors.hsl2rgb(hue - (int)hue, Math.min(Math.max(saturation, 0f), 1f), lum, opacity));
851    }
852
853
854    /**
855     * Given a packed float CIELAB color, this edits its L, A, B, and alpha channels by adding the corresponding "add"
856     * parameter and then clamping. This returns a different float value (of course, the given float can't be edited
857     * in-place). You can give a value of 0 for any "add" parameter you want to stay unchanged. This clamps the
858     * resulting color so it contains in-range L, A, B, and alpha values, but it doesn't guarantee it stays in-gamut.
859     * @param encoded a packed float CIELAB color
860     * @param addL how much to add to the L channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
861     * @param addA how much to add to the A channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
862     * @param addB how much to add to the B channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
863     * @param addAlpha how much to add to the alpha channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
864     * @return a packed float CIELAB color with the requested edits applied to {@code encoded}
865     */
866    public static float editCIELAB(float encoded, float addL, float addA, float addB, float addAlpha) {
867        return editCIELAB(encoded, addL, addA, addB, addAlpha, 1f, 1f, 1f, 1f);
868    }
869    /**
870     * Given a packed float CIELAB color, this edits its L, A, B, and alpha channels by first multiplying each channel
871     * by the corresponding "mul" parameter and then adding the corresponding "add" parameter, before clamping. This
872     * means the lightness value {@code L} is multiplied by {@code mulL}, then has {@code addL} added, and then is
873     * clamped to the normal range for L (0 to 1). This returns a different float value (of course, the given float
874     * can't be edited in-place). You can give a value of 0 for any "add" parameter you want to stay unchanged, or a
875     * value of 1 for any "mul" parameter that shouldn't change. Note that this manipulates A and B in the -0.5 to 0.5
876     * range, so if you multiply by a small number like {@code 0.25f}, then this will produce a less-saturated color,
877     * and if you multiply by a larger number like {@code 4f}, then you will get a much more-saturated color. This
878     * clamps the resulting color so it contains in-range L, A, B, and alpha values, but it doesn't guarantee it stays
879     * in-gamut.
880     * @param encoded a packed float CIELAB color
881     * @param addL how much to add to the L channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
882     * @param addA how much to add to the A channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
883     * @param addB how much to add to the B channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
884     * @param addAlpha how much to add to the alpha channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
885     * @param mulL how much to multiply the L channel by; should be non-negative
886     * @param mulA how much to multiply the A channel by; usually non-negative (not always)
887     * @param mulB how much to multiply the B channel by; usually non-negative (not always)
888     * @param mulAlpha how much to multiply the alpha channel by; should be non-negative
889     * @return a packed float CIELAB color with the requested edits applied to {@code encoded}
890     */
891    public static float editCIELAB(float encoded, float addL, float addA, float addB, float addAlpha,
892                                  float mulL, float mulA, float mulB, float mulAlpha) {
893        final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
894        float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
895        float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f)  * (0.2f / 127.5f);
896        float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
897        float alpha = (decoded >>> 25) / 127f;
898
899        L = Math.min(Math.max(L * mulL + addL, 0f), 1f);
900        A = Math.min(Math.max(A * mulA + addA * 2f, -1f), 1f) * 0.5f;
901        B = Math.min(Math.max(B * mulB + addB * 2f, -1f), 1f) * 0.5f;
902        alpha = Math.min(Math.max(alpha * mulAlpha + addAlpha, 0f), 1f);
903        return clamp(L, A, B, alpha);
904    }
905
906    /**
907     * The "L" channel of the given packed float in CIELAB format, which is its lightness; ranges from 0.0f to
908     * 1.0f . You can edit the L of a color with {@link #lighten(float, float)} and {@link #darken(float, float)}.
909     *
910     * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
911     * @return the L value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
912     */
913    public static float channelL(final float encoded)
914    {
915        return (BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xff) / 255f;
916    }
917
918    /**
919     * The "A" channel of the given packed float in CIELAB format, which when combined with the B channel describes the
920     * hue and saturation of a color; ranges from 0f to 1f . If A is 0f, the color will be cooler, more green or
921     * blue; if A is 1f, the color will be warmer, from magenta to orange. You can edit the A of a color with
922     * {@link #raiseA(float, float)} and {@link #lowerA(float, float)}.
923     * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
924     * @return the A value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
925     */
926    public static float channelA(final float encoded)
927    {
928        return ((BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) >>> 8 & 0xff)) / 255f;
929    }
930
931    /**
932     * The "B" channel of the given packed float in CIELAB format, which when combined with the A channel describes the
933     * hue and saturation of a color; ranges from 0f to 1f . If B is 0f, the color will be more "artificial", more
934     * blue or purple; if B is 1f, the color will be more "natural", from green to yellow to orange. You can edit
935     * the B of a color with {@link #raiseB(float, float)} and {@link #lowerB(float, float)}.
936     * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
937     * @return the B value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
938     */
939    public static float channelB(final float encoded)
940    {
941        return ((BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) >>> 16 & 0xff)) / 255f;
942    }
943
944    /**
945     * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards white by change. While change should be between 0f (return
946     * start as-is) and 1f (return white), start should be a packed color, as from
947     * {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
948     * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
949     * towards white. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and both
950     * chroma of start as-is.
951     * @see #darken(float, float) the counterpart method that darkens a float color
952     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
953     * @param change how much to go from start toward white, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to white
954     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and white
955     */
956    public static float lighten(final float start, final float change) {
957        final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), i = s & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFFFF00;
958        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (i + (0xFF - i) * change) & 0xFF) | other);
959    }
960
961    /**
962     * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards black by change. While change should be between 0f (return
963     * start as-is) and 1f (return black), start should be a packed color, as from
964     * {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
965     * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
966     * towards black. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and both
967     * chroma of start as-is.
968     * @see #lighten(float, float) the counterpart method that lightens a float color
969     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
970     * @param change how much to go from start toward black, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to black
971     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and black
972     */
973    public static float darken(final float start, final float change) {
974        final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), i = s & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFFFF00;
975        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (i * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) | other);
976    }
977
978    /**
979     * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a warmer color (orange to magenta) by change. While change
980     * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully warmed), start should be a packed color, as from
981     * {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors,
982     * and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to
983     * lerp towards a warmer color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the
984     * alpha and L of start as-is.
985     * @see #lowerA(float, float) the counterpart method that cools a float color
986     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
987     * @param change how much to warm start, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a warmer result
988     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a warmer color
989     */
990    public static float raiseA(final float start, final float change) {
991        final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), p = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
992        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (p + (0xFF - p) * change) << 8 & 0xFF00) | other);
993    }
994
995    /**
996     * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a cooler color (green to blue) by change. While change
997     * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully cooled), start should be a packed color, as from
998     * {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
999     * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
1000     * towards a cooler color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and
1001     * L of start as-is.
1002     * @see #raiseA(float, float) the counterpart method that warms a float color
1003     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
1004     * @param change how much to cool start, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a cooler result
1005     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a cooler color
1006     */
1007    public static float lowerA(final float start, final float change) {
1008        final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), p = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
1009        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (p * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) << 8 | other);
1010    }
1011
1012    /**
1013     * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a "natural" color (between green and orange) by change.
1014     * While change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully natural), start should be a packed
1015     * color, as from {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary
1016     * Colors, and is a little more efficient and clear than using
1017     * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards a more natural color. Unlike
1018     * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and L of start as-is.
1019     * @see #lowerB(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less natural
1020     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
1021     * @param change how much to change start to a natural color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more natural result
1022     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a more natural color
1023     */
1024    public static float raiseB(final float start, final float change) {
1025        final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), t = s >>> 16 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFE00FFFF;
1026        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (t + (0xFF - t) * change) << 16 & 0xFF0000) | other);
1027    }
1028
1029    /**
1030     * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards an "artificial" color (between blue and purple) by change.
1031     * While change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully artificial), start should be a packed
1032     * color, as from {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary
1033     * Colors, and is a little more efficient and clear than using
1034     * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards a more artificial color. Unlike
1035     * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and L of start as-is.
1036     * @see #raiseB(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less artificial
1037     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
1038     * @param change how much to change start to a bolder color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more artificial result
1039     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a more artificial color
1040     */
1041    public static float lowerB(final float start, final float change) {
1042        final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), t = s >>> 16 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFE00FFFF;
1043        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (t * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) << 16 | other);
1044    }
1045
1046    /**
1047     * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards that color made opaque by change. While change should be
1048     * between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return start with full alpha), start should be a packed color, as from
1049     * {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
1050     * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
1051     * towards transparent. This won't change the L, A, or B of the color.
1052     * @see #fade(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more translucent
1053     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
1054     * @param change how much to go from start toward opaque, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to opaque
1055     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and its opaque version
1056     */
1057    public static float blot(final float start, final float change) {
1058        final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), opacity = s >>> 24 & 0xFE, other = s & 0x00FFFFFF;
1059        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (opacity + (0xFE - opacity) * change) & 0xFE) << 24 | other);
1060    }
1061
1062    /**
1063     * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards transparent by change. While change should be between 0
1064     * (return start as-is) and 1f (return the color with 0 alpha), start should be a packed color, as from
1065     * {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors,
1066     * and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to
1067     * lerp towards transparent. This won't change the L, A, or B of the color.
1068     * @see #blot(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more opaque
1069     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
1070     * @param change how much to go from start toward transparent, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to transparent
1071     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and transparent
1072     */
1073    public static float fade(final float start, final float change) {
1074        final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), opacity = s & 0xFE, other = s & 0x00FFFFFF;
1075        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (opacity * (1f - change)) & 0xFE) << 24 | other);
1076    }
1077
1078    /**
1079     * Brings the chromatic components of {@code start} closer to grayscale by {@code change} (desaturating them). While
1080     * change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully gray), start should be a packed color, as
1081     * from {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}. This only changes A and B; it leaves L and alpha alone.
1082     * @see #enrich(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more saturated
1083     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
1084     * @param change how much to change start to a desaturated color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a less saturated result
1085     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a desaturated color
1086     */
1087    public static float dullen(final float start, final float change) {
1088        final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start);
1089        return cielab((s & 0xFF) / 255f,
1090                ((s >>> 8 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f - change) + 0.5f,
1091                ((s >>> 16 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f - change) + 0.5f,
1092                (s >>> 25) / 127f);
1093    }
1094
1095    /**
1096     * Pushes the chromatic components of {@code start} away from grayscale by change (saturating them). While change
1097     * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return maximally saturated), start should be a packed color, as
1098     * from {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}. This changes only A and B. This prevents high values for change
1099     * from pushing A or B out of the valid range by using {@link #clamp(float, float, float, float)}; this doesn't
1100     * actually keep the color in-gamut, but usually rendering code can handle out-of-gamut colors in some way.
1101     * Alpha. The alpha never changes. It never changes L either.
1102     * @see #dullen(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less saturated
1103     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
1104     * @param change how much to change start to a saturated color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more saturated result
1105     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a saturated color
1106     */
1107    public static float enrich(final float start, final float change) {
1108        final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start);
1109        return clamp((s & 0xFF) / 255f,
1110                ((s >>> 8 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f + change) + 0.5f,
1111                ((s >>> 16 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f + change) + 0.5f,
1112                (s >>> 25) / 127f);
1113    }
1114
1115    /**
1116     * Given a packed float CIELAB color {@code mainColor} and another CIELAB color that it should be made to contrast with,
1117     * gets a packed float CIELAB color with roughly inverted intnsity but the same chromatic channels and opacity (P and T
1118     * are likely to be clamped if the result gets close to white or black). This won't ever produce black or other very
1119     * dark colors, and also has a gap in the range it produces for intensity values between 0.5 and 0.55. That allows
1120     * most of the colors this method produces to contrast well as a foreground when displayed on a background of
1121     * {@code contrastingColor}, or vice versa. This will leave the intensity unchanged if the chromatic channels of the
1122     * contrastingColor and those of the mainColor are already very different. This has nothing to do with the contrast
1123     * channel of the tweak in ColorfulBatch; where that part of the tweak can make too-similar lightness values further
1124     * apart by just a little, this makes a modification on {@code mainColor} to maximize its lightness difference from
1125     * {@code contrastingColor} without losing its other qualities.
1126     * @param mainColor a packed float color, as produced by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}; this is the color that will be adjusted
1127     * @param contrastingColor a packed float color, as produced by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}; the adjusted mainColor will contrast with this
1128     * @return a different CIELAB packed float color, based on mainColor but with potentially very different lightness
1129     */
1130    public static float inverseLightness(final float mainColor, final float contrastingColor)
1131    {
1132        final int bits = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor),
1133                contrastBits = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(contrastingColor),
1134                L = (bits & 0xff),
1135                A = (bits >>> 8 & 0xff),
1136                B = (bits >>> 16 & 0xff),
1137                cL = (contrastBits & 0xff),
1138                cA = (contrastBits >>> 8 & 0xff),
1139                cB = (contrastBits >>> 16 & 0xff);
1140        if((A - cA) * (A - cA) + (B - cB) * (B - cB) >= 0x10000)
1141            return mainColor;
1142        return cielab(cL < 128 ? L * (0.45f / 255f) + 0.5f : 0.5f - L * (0.45f / 255f), A / 255f, B / 255f, 0x1.0p-8f * (bits >>> 24));
1143    }
1144
1145    /**
1146     * Given a packed float CIELAB color {@code mainColor} and another CIELAB color that it should be made to contrast
1147     * with, gets a packed float CIELAB color with L that should be quite different from {@code contrastingColor}'s L,
1148     * but the same chromatic channels and opacity (A and B are likely to be clamped if the result gets close to white
1149     * or black). This allows most of the colors this method produces to contrast well as a foreground when displayed on
1150     * a background of {@code contrastingColor}, or vice versa.
1151     * <br>
1152     * This is similar to {@link #inverseLightness(float, float)}, but is considerably simpler, and this method will
1153     * change the lightness of mainColor when the two given colors have close lightness but distant chroma. Because it
1154     * averages the original L of mainColor with the modified one, this tends to not produce harsh color changes.
1155     * @param mainColor a packed CIELAB float color; this is the color that will be adjusted
1156     * @param contrastingColor a packed CIELAB float color; the adjusted mainColor will contrast with the I of this
1157     * @return a different packed CIELAB float color, based on mainColor but typically with different lightness
1158     */
1159    public static float differentiateLightness(final float mainColor, final float contrastingColor)
1160    {
1161        final int main = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor), contrast = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(contrastingColor);
1162        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((main & 0xFEFFFF00) | (contrast + 128 & 0xFF) + (main & 0xFF) >>> 1);
1163    }
1164
1165    /**
1166     * Pretty simple; adds 0.5 to the given color's L and wraps it around if it would go above 1.0, then averages that
1167     * with the original L. This means light colors become darker, and dark colors become lighter, with almost all
1168     * results in the middle-range of possible lightness.
1169     * @param mainColor a packed CIELAB float color
1170     * @return a different packed CIELAB float color, with its L channel changed and limited to the correct gamut
1171     */
1172    public static float offsetLightness(final float mainColor) {
1173        final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor);
1174        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((decoded & 0xFEFFFF00) | (decoded + 128 & 0xFF) + (decoded & 0xFF) >>> 1);
1175    }
1176
1177    /**
1178     * Makes the additive CIELAB color stored in {@code color} cause less of a change when used as a tint, as if it were
1179     * mixed with neutral gray. When {@code fraction} is 1.0, this returns color unchanged; when fraction is 0.0, it
1180     * 50% gray, and when it is in-between 0.0 and 1.0 it returns something between the two. This is
1181     * meant for things like area of effect abilities that make smaller color changes toward their periphery.
1182     * @param color a color that should have its tinting effect potentially weakened
1183     * @param fraction how much of {@code color} should be kept, from 0.0 to 1.0
1184     * @return a CIELAB float color between gray and {@code color}
1185     */
1186    public static float lessenChange(final float color, float fraction) {
1187        final int e = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(color),
1188                sL = 0x80, sA = 0x80, sB = 0x80,
1189                eL = (e & 0xFF), eA = (e >>> 8) & 0xFF, eB = (e >>> 16) & 0xFF, eAlpha = e >>> 24 & 0xFE;
1190        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (sL + fraction * (eL - sL)) & 0xFF)
1191                | (((int) (sA + fraction * (eA - sA)) & 0xFF) << 8)
1192                | (((int) (sB + fraction * (eB - sB)) & 0xFF) << 16)
1193                | (eAlpha << 24));
1194    }
1195
1196    /**
1197     * Returns true if the given packed float color, as CIELAB, is valid to convert losslessly back to RGBA.
1198     * @param packed a packed float color as CIELAB
1199     * @return true if the given packed float color can be converted back and forth to RGBA
1200     */
1201    public static boolean inGamut(final float packed)
1202    {
1203        final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
1204        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*((decoded & 0xff) / 255f + 0.16f);
1205        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) *  (0.2f / 127.5f);
1206        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
1207        final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A);
1208        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
1209        final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B);
1210        final float r = +3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z;
1211        if(r <= -0x1p-8f || r >= 0x1.01p0f) return false;
1212        final float g = -0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z;
1213        if(g <= -0x1p-8f || g >= 0x1.01p0f) return false;
1214        final float b = +0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z;
1215        return (b > -0x1p-8f && b < 0x1.01p0f);
1216
1217//        final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
1218//        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*((decoded & 0xff) / 255f + 0.16f);
1219//        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) *  (0.2f / 127.5f);
1220//        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
1221//        final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A);
1222//        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
1223//        final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B);
1224//        boolean ret = true;
1225//        final float r = +3.2406f * x + -1.5372f * y + -0.4986f * z;
1226////        final float r = +3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z;
1227//        if(r <= -0x1p-8f || r >= 0x1.01p0f) ret = false;
1228////        final float g = -0.9689f * x + +1.8758f * y + +0.0415f * z;
1229//        final float g = -0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z;
1230//        if(g <= -0x1p-8f || g >= 0x1.01p0f) ret = false;
1231////        final float b = +0.0557f * x + -0.2040f * y + +1.0570f * z;
1232//        final float b = +0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z;
1233//        ret &= (b > -0x1p-8f && b < 0x1.01p0f);
1234//        if(!ret) System.out.printf("L %f, A %f, B %f, x %f, y %f, z %f, r %f, g %f, b %f\n", L, A, B,  x, y, z,  r, g, b);
1235//        return ret;
1236
