1237    }
1238
1239    /**
1240     * Returns true if the given CIELAB values are valid to convert losslessly back to RGBA.
1241     * @param L lightness, as a float from 0 to 1
1242     * @param A cyan-to-red chroma, as a float from 0 to 1
1243     * @param B blue-to-yellow chroma, as a float from 0 to 1
1244     * @return true if the given packed float color can be converted back and forth to RGBA
1245     */
1246    public static boolean inGamut(float L, float A, float B)
1247    {
1248        L = (1f/1.16f)*(L + 0.16f);
1249        A = (A - 0.5f) * (0.4f);
1250        B = (B - 0.5f);
1251        final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A);
1252        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
1253        final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B);
1254        final float r = +3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z;
1255        if(r < 0f || r > 1.0f) return false;
1256        final float g = -0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z;
1257        if(g < 0f || g > 1.0f) return false;
1258        final float b = +0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z;
1259        return (b >= 0f && b <= 1.0f);
1260    }
1261
1262    /**
1263     * Iteratively checks whether the given CIELAB color is in-gamut, and either brings the color closer to grayscale if
1264     * it isn't in-gamut, or returns it as soon as it is in-gamut. Maintains the L of the color, only bringing A and B
1265     * closer to grayscale. Note that this version of limitToGamut() is much slower than Oklab's version, because Oklab
1266     * stores its entire gamut as a large constant, while this has to calculate it.
1267     * @param packed a packed float color in CIELAB format; often this color is not in-gamut
1268     * @return the first color this finds that is between the given CIELAB color and grayscale, and is in-gamut
1269     * @see #inGamut(float) You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
1270     */
1271    public static float limitToGamut(final float packed) {
1272        final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
1273        final float L = (1f/1.16f)*((decoded & 0xff) / 255f + 0.16f);
1274        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) *  (0.2f / 127.5f);
1275        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
1276        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
1277        float A2 = A, B2 = B;
1278        for (int attempt = 127; attempt >= 0; attempt--) {
1279            final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A2);
1280            final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B2);
1281            final float r = reverseGamma(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z);
1282            final float g = reverseGamma(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z);
1283            final float b = reverseGamma(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z);
1284            if(r >= 0f && r <= 1f && g >= 0f && g <= 1f && b >= 0f && b <= 1f)
1285                break;
1286            final float progress = attempt * 0x1p-7f;
1287            A2 = (A * progress);
1288            B2 = (B * progress);
1289        }
1290        return cielab(L, A2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, B2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, (decoded >>> 25) / 127f);
1291    }
1292
1293    /**
1294     * Iteratively checks whether the given CIELAB color is in-gamut, and either brings the color closer to grayscale if it
1295     * isn't in-gamut, or returns it as soon as it is in-gamut. Maintains the L of the color, only bringing A and B
1296     * closer to grayscale. This always produces an opaque color.
1297     * @param L lightness; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1298     * @param A cyan-to-red chroma; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1299     * @param B blue-to-yellow chroma; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1300     * @return the first color this finds that is between the given CIELAB color and grayscale, and is in-gamut
1301     * @see #inGamut(float, float, float)  You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
1302     */
1303    public static float limitToGamut(float L, float A, float B) {
1304        return limitToGamut(L, A, B, 1f);
1305    }
1306    /**
1307     * Iteratively checks whether the given CIELAB color is in-gamut, and either brings the color closer to grayscale if it
1308     * isn't in-gamut, or returns it as soon as it is in-gamut. Note that this version of limitToGamut() is much slower
1309     * than Oklab's version, because Oklab stores its entire gamut as a large constant, while this has to calculate it.
1310     * @param L lightness; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1311     * @param A cyan-to-red chroma; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1312     * @param B blue-to-yellow chroma; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1313     * @param alpha opacity; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1314     * @return the first color this finds that is between the given CIELAB color and grayscale, and is in-gamut
1315     * @see #inGamut(float, float, float)  You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
1316     */
1317    public static float limitToGamut(float L, float A, float B, float alpha) {
1318
1319        L = (1f/1.16f)*(Math.min(Math.max(L, 0f), 1f) + 0.16f);
1320        A = (Math.min(Math.max(A, 0f), 1f) - 0.5f) * 0.4f;
1321        B = (Math.min(Math.max(B, 0f), 1f) - 0.5f);
1322        alpha = Math.min(Math.max(alpha, 0f), 1f);
1323
1324        final float y = reverseXYZ(L);
1325        float A2 = A, B2 = B;
1326        for (int attempt = 127; attempt >= 0; attempt--) {
1327            final float x = reverseXYZ(L + A2);
1328            final float z = reverseXYZ(L - B2);
1329            final float r = reverseGamma(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z);
1330            final float g = reverseGamma(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z);
1331            final float b = reverseGamma(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z);
1332            if(r >= 0f && r <= 1f && g >= 0f && g <= 1f && b >= 0f && b <= 1f)
1333                break;
1334            final float progress = attempt * 0x1p-7f;
1335            A2 = (A * progress);
1336            B2 = (B * progress);
1337        }
1338        return cielab(L, A2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, B2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, alpha);
1339    }
1340
1341    /**
1342     * Makes a quasi-randomly-edited variant on the given {@code color}, allowing typically a small amount of
1343     * {@code variance} (such as 0.05 to 0.25) between the given color and what this can return. The {@code seed} should
1344     * be different each time this is called, and can be obtained from a random number generator to make the colors more
1345     * random, or can be incremented on each call. If the seed is only incremented or decremented, then this shouldn't
1346     * produce two similar colors in a row unless variance is very small. The variance affects the L, A, and B of the
1347     * generated color, and each of those channels can go up or down by the given variance as long as the total distance
1348     * isn't greater than the variance (this considers A and B extra-wide, going from -1 to 1, while L goes from 0 to 1,
1349     * but only internally for measuring distance).
1350     * @param color a packed float color, as produced by {@link #cielab(float, float, float, float)}
1351     * @param seed a long seed that should be different on each call; should not be 0
1352     * @param variance max amount of difference between the given color and the generated color; always less than 1
1353     * @return a generated packed float color that should be at least somewhat different from {@code color}
1354     */
1355    public static float randomEdit(final float color, long seed, final float variance) {
1356        final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(color);
1357        final float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
1358        final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) *  (0.2f / 127.5f);
1359        final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) * (0.5f / 127.5f);
1360        final float limit = variance * variance;
1361        float dist, x, y, z;
1362        for (int j = 0; j < 50; j++) {
1363            x = (((seed * 0xD1B54A32D192ED03L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
1364            y = (((seed * 0xABC98388FB8FAC03L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
1365            z = (((seed * 0x8CB92BA72F3D8DD7L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
1366            seed += 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L;
1367            dist = x * x + y * y + z * z;
1368            if(dist <= limit)
1369                return clamp(x + L, (A + y) * 0.5f + 0.5f, (B + z) * 0.5f + 0.5f, (decoded >>> 25) / 127f);
1370        }
1371        return color;
1372    }
1373
1374    /**
1375     * Produces a random packed float color that is always in-gamut and should be uniformly distributed.
1376     * @param random a Random object (preferably a subclass of Random, like {@link com.github.tommyettinger.digital.AlternateRandom})
1377     * @return a packed float color that is always in-gamut
1378     */
1379    public static float randomColor(Random random) {
1380        float L = random.nextFloat();
1381        float A = random.nextFloat();
1382        float B = random.nextFloat();
1383        while (!inGamut(L, A, B)) {
1384            L = random.nextFloat();
1385            A = random.nextFloat();
1386            B = random.nextFloat();
1387        }
1388        return cielab(L, A, B, 1f);
1389    }
1390
1391        /**
1392         * Produces a random packed float color that is always in-gamut (and opaque) and should be uniformly distributed.
1393     * This is only present for legacy compatibility; new code should use {@link #randomColor(Random)}.
1394     * @param random a Random object (or preferably a subclass of Random, like {@link com.github.tommyettinger.digital.AlternateRandom})
1395     * @return a packed float color that is always in-gamut
1396     * @deprecated Use {@link #randomColor(Random)} instead.
1397     */
1398    @Deprecated
1399    public static float randomizedColor(Random random) {
1400        float L = random.nextFloat();
1401        float A = random.nextFloat();
1402        float B = random.nextFloat();
1403        while (!inGamut(L, A, B)) {
1404            L = random.nextFloat();
1405            A = random.nextFloat();
1406            B = random.nextFloat();
1407        }
1408        return cielab(L, A, B, 1f);
1409    }
